name: European Music
description: Regional styles with roots in the European continent and surrounding islands.

children.name: Alpenrock
children.description: Mixes Hard Rock and Blues Rock with traditional Alpine Folk Music elements such as Yodeling and use of the accordion.

children.name: Ancient Roman Music
children.description: Music of ancient Roman civilization.

children.name: Anglican Chant
children.description: Simple, harmonized, English-language setting of the Christian liturgy, principally devised by the Anglican Church.

children.name: Ashkenazi Music
children.description: Encompasses the various traditions and genres of the Ashkenazi Jews, an ethnoreligious group that was prominent and influential in Europe throughout most of the Middle Ages and the modern period.

children.name: Balkan Music
children.description: Meta-genre covering all forms developed in the Balkan Peninsula.

children.name: Baroque Music
children.description: Constant rhythmic flow, or a steady motion throughout, generally focusing on a single melodic idea and including some form of counterpoint.

children.name: Baroque Suite
children.description: Collection of varied dance pieces, usually in the same key, structured on the music of European courtly dances.

children.name: British Music
children.description: Music of Great Britain, including the music of the English, Welsh and Scottish people.

children.name: Caucasian Music
children.description: Music of the region of the Caucasus, a mountainous region bordered by Russia to the north and Turkey/Iran to the south, with the Black and Caspian seas to its sides.

children.name: Celtic Electronica
children.description: Fusion of Celtic Folk Music with various types of Electronic Dance Music.

children.name: Celtic Metal
children.description: Features Celtic Folk Music elements.

children.name: Celtic New Age
children.description: Incorporates influences and performing styles from Celtic Folk Music, emphasizing pastoral imagery and wistful themes.

children.name: Celtic Punk
children.description: Infuses the sounds of Celtic Folk Music into Punk Rock.

children.name: Celtic Rock
children.description: Incorporates influences from Celtic Folk Music and its regional variants.

children.name: Chanson
children.description: French-language Singer-Songwriters for whom the quality of the text is essential and where the rhythm follows that of the text.

children.name: Classical Period
children.description: Refers to the phase in Western Classical Music history occurring from roughly 1750 to 1820, characterized by its emphasis on clarity, simplicity, and balance.

children.name: Country & Irish
children.description: Developed in Ireland; combines North American Country with Irish Folk Music influences, often in the form of traditional Irish songs that have been adapted into country numbers.

children.name: Crimean Tatar Music
children.description: Music of the Crimean Tatar people, a Turkic ethnic group indigenous to the Crimean Peninsula, located in southern Ukraine.

children.name: Dechovka
children.description: Brass band genre popular in Czechia and Slovakia, characterized by lively brass instrumentation, infectious rhythms, and vibrant melodies.

children.name: Dutch Cabaret
children.description: Popular comedy form in the Netherlands which evolved out of traditional Cabaret in the 1890s.

children.name: European Folk Music
children.description: Encompasses numerous folk traditions found in Europe.

children.name: Fanfare
children.description: Brass-led tradition originating in Western Europe, commonly performed during important public events, typically featuring a ceremonious, triumphant, or uplifting sound.

children.name: Finnish Tango
children.description: Melancholic style developed in Finland in the 1930s and 1940s, influenced by traditional minor-key Finnish Folk Music melodies and the rhythms of German marches.

children.name: German Music
children.description: Music of the German-speaking people, spanning predominately central Europe, primarily Germany, Austria, and Switzerland, among others.

children.name: Grand opéra
children.description: French style characterized by its enlarged scope and sense of grandeur, with bigger orchestras and casts, and ornate sceneries and costumes.

children.name: Greek Music
children.description: Music of the Greek people.

children.name: Iberian Music
children.description: Music of the Iberian peninsula.

children.name: Irish Showband
children.description: Phenomenon lasting from the mid-1950s until the early 1980s, often performed a mixture of currently popular music and skits.

children.name: Italian Music
children.description: Music of the Italian people.

children.name: Kabarett
children.description: Theatrical entertainment consisting of mixed elements of music, sketches, monologues, dialogues, lyric poetry and/or ballads.

children.name: Kalmyk Music
children.description: Music of the Kalmyks, a Mongol Buddhist ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Kalmykia, a federal subject of the Russian Federation.

children.name: Kleinkunst
children.description: Dutch-language genre from the Netherlands and Flanders with influences from Cabaret, protest songs, Chanson, and folk.

children.name: Kyivan Chant
children.description: Chant form inspired by Znamenny Chant that's characterized by simplified melodic and rhythmic structures.

children.name: Madrigal
children.description: Secular polyphonic music based around poetry and generally performed by unaccompanied vocal ensembles of two to eight persons.

children.name: Medieval Classical Music
children.description: Composed during the Medieval period lasted approximately from the 5th to the late 15th centuries.

children.name: Mittelalter-Metal
children.description: Emerged as a metallic style in the mid-to-late 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement.

children.name: Mittelalter-Rock
children.description: Emerged in the 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement, incorporating medieval instruments with Rock music.

children.name: Mulatós
children.description: Upbeat, danceable Hungarian Pop that takes strong influence from Hungarian Folk Music and Romani Folk Music.

children.name: Mélodie
children.description: French form typically with a greater emphasis on emotional restraint, refinement, subtlety, and concision.

children.name: Nordic Music
children.description: Music from the Nordic countries, including Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, and Finland.

children.name: Nòva cançon
children.description: Arose in the Occitania region of southern France, sung in the Occitan language as a way to preserve their culture and resist forced usage of French.

children.name: Opéra-comique
children.description: French style of Opera characterized by the use of some spoken dialogues to connect major arias and sung parts, as well as a more restrained approach to recitatives.

children.name: Polish Music
children.description: Music rooted in the traditions of the Poles.

children.name: Renaissance Music
children.description: Encompasses Western Classical Music from the 15th to 16th centuries.

children.name: Romanian Music
children.description: Music of the Romanian people.

children.name: Russian Music
children.description: Music of the Russian people.

children.name: Schlager
children.description: Light, sentimental, melodic pop music common mainly in northern and central Europe.

children.name: Singspiel
children.description: German form of Opera distinguished by the prominent usage of spoken dialogues mixed with lyrical or folklore arias/ballads.

children.name: Tragédie en musique
children.description: French Opera genre developed by Jean-Baptiste Lully and Philippe Quinault in the second half of the 17th century, consisting of alterations made to the coeval Italian format to better fit the French language and please an audience more accustomed to the ballet de cour.

children.name: Trampská hudba
children.description: Associated with the tramping lifestyle, typically mixing acoustic guitar driven Contemporary Folk with strong Country influences and vocal harmonies in peaceful, simple and relatively short songs.

children.name: Verismo
children.description: Developed in Italy around the turn of the 20th century and favored melodramatic realism, a rejection of bel canto standards, and declamatory singing.

children.name: Waltz
children.description: Typically in a 3/4 time signature and popular in the 18th century in central Europe, as it accompanied the ballroom dance of the same name.
